Posts.Content: Lifes-A-Beach wrote: After not having an US on my left breast for 2yrs, today is the day!!! It comes with mixed feelings relief that I will finally see what the changes that I have been feeling are (can not see on mammo heterogenously dense breast) but worried because no doctor wanted to follow up on these except for mammo as they catergorized the one as a fibroadenoma..Now I have 2 more lumps, thickened tissue and a sore lump near armpit..Hopefully when I tell the tech they need to take there time and where they need to view they dont get mad but dangit I need all of these areas checked as they have changed or are new.. Sorry for the vent but sometimes you just have to write it out as no one in the fam gives a darn.. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Finally An Ultrasound!!! Lifes-A-Beach Kaara

Posts.Content: Beach wrote: I wanted to share my story just in case other people might be experiencing the same thing and/or find that no one is listening.  So far I have had 3 cycles of FEC and 2 cycles of Taxotere and Herceptin.  I tolerated the FEC extremely well but can't say the same for Taxotere.  I developed what they are now calling a severe toxic reaction mainly on my hands and a little on my face and neck one week after the first tx of Taxotere.  Unfortunately I couldn't get my med onc to see me (didn't seem to be concerned in the slightest), but I took pictures when all of the skin peeled off of my hands just prior to my 2nd tx.  Unfortunately again, the day of my 2nd tx my med onc was away so I saw her resident doc and a "supply med onc" who both listened, looked at my pics and even spoke with other oncs to decide how to proceed that day, but in the end decided to give me the Taxotere at the same dosage.  Three days after this tx, the reaction started on my hands, face and neck and over the course of three more days became quite severe on my neck and face........it looks like a burn that's happening from the inside out...........I basically looked like an Alien!!  Again I called my med onc's office and again no one would see me, but they did phone a prescription into my pharmacist for a hydro-cortisone cream.......didn't help at all.  I saw my family doctor two days ago, which was now 9 days after the 2nd tx, who took one look at me, and immediately called my med onc to make things happen......finally!!  Crazy how my med onc wouldn't listen to me but took things more seriously once my family doc called, who by the way also had to convince her that I was not a "high-maintenance" patient.  It's now day 11 and my skin is peeling off my neck (which has looked like tight, wrinkly elephant skin for the last few days), and a little off my face..........extremely uncomfortable and quite ugly to look at The decision has been made to take me off of Taxotere as this is considered quite serious and my med onc also confided to my family doc that similar reactions have happened in two of her other patients in the last month or so!!  She also said that the pharmaceutical company has already been approached about this, so in my mind this is happening with many other patients too.  Wondering how many people out there are experiencing a similar severe reaction??? Now my med onc will finally see me this coming Tues to check on me and discuss how to move forward with alternative treatment.......why does it have to take something so severe to get people to listen?? This has been extremely frustrating and I have never felt so alone and beaten up both physically and emotionally........just wondering if there are others going through this?? Sandy Beach Dx 2/5/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Taxotere - BEWARE!! Beach Beach

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2009 08:04AM Beach wrote: Linda--What you said is my hope too, so I gave my onc some pics that she could use for future cases if necessary .  She also had both of her resident docs come into my room after the fact to take a look at my reaction.  She is having me continue Decadron for 5 more days....just want a good night's sleep soon!  Due to my appearance I haven't been leaving the house much since all of this started back in mid June, but not even being able to sit under an umbrella in my back yard will be difficult.......I have a little pond, fountain and lots of shrubs and flowers.....this has become my sanctuary over the last few months!!  Oh well, must look at the bigger picture and do what I can to reverse this reaction.  Hugs and many thanks to you! Terry--My goodness what you had to endure.........completely unacceptable.......I am so sorry!!!  These oncs/health care professionals need to be constantly reminded that we are entrusting them with our treatment and our lives for that matter.  For so many of us this is our first time going through tx and experiencing these issues and se's and it's ALL concerning for us!  We need to be listened to and treated as individual cases because what might be "old hat" for them is now our "new normal".  From the reading I've done on these boards, we do not have cookie cutter se's, and there obviously is not a one size fits all solution !!   Thanks for sharing your experience and all the best to you!! Hugs ((( ))) Sandy
Posts.Title: Taxotere - BEWARE!! Beach Beach

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2009 09:08AM Beach wrote: So sorry that there are more of you going through similar se's! Texas--Kudos to you for getting through all of your tx on this drug and good to hear that you had no scarring.  I agree with you about the Decadron.....haven't slept properly since I've been on it but it seems to be having some effect on my face.  The skin on my neck and hands is completely peeling away now, but again, this is hopefully part of the healing process.  I did have mouth issues but more so after the first tx.  I used their prescribed mouth wash after the second tx when I felt these same se's starting and it stopped it from getting worse.  My nails on my hands started changing colours after the first tx but I used the cooling mitts during and after the second tx and it seems to have reversed this condition.  All the best to you!! MicheleS--Thanks for your post and kind words.  I had read about Abraxane before my second tx and brought it up with the resident doc and "supply onc" but was told it is not used in Canada??!!  I will be asking my actual onc about this again tomorrow.  I have also printed off the Taxotere Dosage Manual from the manufacturer which suggests if a reaction similar to mine occurs, that they recommend lowering the dose.......will question why this wasn't done.  Take care and hugs to you too!! Anna--Wow my se's seem small compared to what you are going through....sooo sorry!!  I applaud your strength and perseverance but find myself questioning why your onc is not providing you with an alternative tx option.  It does however sound as though she is listening and doing what she can to help alleviate your se's.  This is all hard enough without having to go through your many horrible se's!  All the best to you and I hope you have an easier time of it on your last tx. Bettysgirl--I completely agree......FEC was a walk in the park compared to Taxotere.  In fact I was functioning quite well by the middle of week 2 and 3 after each FEC treatment.  Unfortunately this has not been the case on Taxotere.  My best functioning days have been the first two days after tx while the Decadron is in my system and the day before the next tx.  Other than that I've been pretty much a "shut-in" except for my outing to my family doc last week.....also, not strong enough to handle the stares from people who just don't know or understand :-(((  Glad to hear you tolerated it better after they lowered your dose.  I believe that the docs overseeing me while my onc was absent were afraid to make that exact decision without her weighing in on it.......she has an heir of intimidation about her!!  I will be asking her all kinds of questions tomorrow, without "challenging" her of course .  Thanks for your input and hope all is well with you!! Will post after my meeting with my onc tomorrow......thanks again to everybody...................... big HUGS ((( ))) Sandy
Posts.Title: Taxotere - BEWARE!! Beach Beach

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2009 10:08AM Beach wrote: Texas..... That's funny......my neighbourhood pharmacist now knows me quite well.........well right now you can see me coming a mile away, freakish-looking alien that I am.  Oh don't forget the "Anusol" and "Replense"......I had reactions down there as well after the first tx.  Sorry about your tear duct problem! Like you said, I will get through this and it will get better......BELIEVE!!!
Posts.Title: Taxotere - BEWARE!! Beach Beach

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2009 01:43PM Beach wrote: Back from seeing my "actual" oncologist......finally!!!!  Although she admits she has not seen anything this severe, she has decided that my reaction resulted from a combination of toxicity from the Taxotere and a sun/light sensitivity that I developed eventhough I have not been in the sun at all.  Now she insists that I remain indoors for the next 3 weeks or so until the Taxotere fully leaves my system and this reaction reverses, which she is confident it will.  Result:  No more Taxotere or any other chemo  moving forward.......she feels I've had enough and still have lots of treatment to go with Herceptin, Tamoxifen and radiation. Thanks for the support you all have shown me through this!!! Sandy
Posts.Title: Taxotere - BEWARE!! Beach Beach

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2009 12:59PM Beach wrote: Jaimieh---Thanks for taking the time to express your kind words....much appreciated.  All the best to you!! Is there no one out there that has or is experiencing something like this.......I'm finding it hard to believe that it's only happening to three of us in Toronto, Canada!!
Posts.Title: Taxotere - BEWARE!! Beach Beach

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2009 02:01PM Beach wrote: Piffken, It's hard to say whether it will come back or not.  Seems to be a wait and see approach for me right now.  Side effects were not too bad initially, (chemo se's at the time over-shadowed them), but they have intensified since I started Tamox.  Have to say that the night sweats and difficulty sleeping are the worst se's for me......so far anyway......I guess only time will tell.  Wishing you all the best through your tx. Sandy
Posts.Title: Vaginal bleeding after first round of chemo anyone? Piffken buttonsmachine

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2009 06:55PM Beach wrote: Piffken, Yes, the se's have been intensifying since I started Tamoxifen which was the end of Aug, just after radiation finished.  Now it is possible that these se's are also intensifying as I get further away from my last period.....hard to say at this point. There are different point of views as to when Tamoxifen should start.  My med onc told me I could start it one month after chemo had finished, but my rad onc wanted me to wait until after radiation because of the reaction I was getting over from chemo.  My chemo tx was supposed to be 6 cycles, one every 3 weeks.  The regimen was 3 x FEC, 3 x Taxotere + 1 year of Herceptin.  FEC was manageable but Taxotere really hit me hard.  I had what they call a "severe toxic reaction" which worsened after my 2nd Taxotere (5th treatment), and consequently, my 6th/final treatment was cancelled.  I am still getting Herceptin infusions every 3 wks which will continue until May 2010.  It's a long road..........this board has been a huge help in making it a little easier! Best, Sandy
Posts.Title: Vaginal bleeding after first round of chemo anyone? Piffken buttonsmachine

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2009 09:08AM Beach wrote: 4 more boosts to go and my rads are finished .  My tx plan was 16 tx plus 5 boosts.  Have a square of redness from under my arm to the middle of my chest, but no broken down skin, and have areas of itchiness but nothing too severe.  My scars don't seem to be affected at this point, but I do have sensitivity issues and twinges of pain in my nipple and surrounding area....... unfortunately, it is part of the area receiving the boosts.  Fatigue has been a factor through this, but I was pretty wiped out prior to starting rads due to a bad reaction from chemo and still dealing with some extreme se's, so it's hard to tell what's causing the fatigue.  Overall my rad experience has not been too bad at all..........I hope this will be the same for all of you! Sandy
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2009 03:06PM Beach wrote: Chiquita--Sorry to hear that you are getting as much empathy and care as I was.  Where are you located?  Hopefully things will start to change in your favour after seeing your family doc.....mine was a lifesaver.  She has even been calling me off hours to see how I'm doing.  Oh and surprise, surprise my med onc's secretary called me yesterday to check in with me too........I think someone's feeling a little negligent! Linda--Thanks again for your response and staying in tune with me and my ongoing issue.  I did follow your advice about the pics before the last tx.........just unfortunate that my actual med onc wasn't there that day.  I have been taking pics throughout this latest reaction and will bring them plus the previous ones on Tues so she can see the differences between each reaction and the rapid progression of what happened this time.  Regardless I will not be on it anymore but maybe this will help someone after me.  I don't know if it's the Tax/Herceptin combo as many women are on this.........lets see what the posts bring.  Hugs and many thanks to you ((( )))!!! Sandy
Posts.Title: Taxotere - BEWARE!! Beach Beach

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2009 08:44AM Beach wrote: Texas--Sounds like you went through the ringer too.....sorry.  In addition to the redness and swelling on my face, my skin has been numb too.....like it's not my own.  This is not the case on my neck or hands though.  Did this all reverse for you?  any scarring?  I've been put on Decadron to try to relieve and reverse all of this.  I respect your opinion on Taxotere for your own case, but I am not willing to take a chance on any further increase of severity if I were to take the last tx.  I think at this point the Herceptin is the most important thing right now for my HER2+. NanaA--You are correct, the decision needs to be individual and reflect our own diagnosis, prognosis and situation.  One week after my first Taxotere tx I had a neuropathy in my feet and finger tips and the body/joint pain was extremely bad, so switching from Taxol to Taxotere could have made things even worse for you.  I'm wondering if my onc will try to switch me over to Taxol, in which case I will say "no nothing from the Taxane family thanks", just give me the Herceptin.  I will then show her the research article I found from May 2009 on this website, "Sequential Docetaxel:  No Benefit in Early Breast Cancer".  It basically states that adding Taxotere to FEC or CMF treatments for early stage bc has shown virtually no improvement on 5 year survival or recurrence rates.  What it did show was that women receiving this drug had a higher risk of serious chemo-related side effects; grade 3 or 4 toxicities.  Again, this pertains to the benefit, or lack thereof, in adding it to adjuvant therapy for early stage bc, NOT its effectiveness in treating advanced or metastatic bc. Lovinmomma--Thanks for your support.....I think they'll be listening now, plus I have lots of pics which will support the progression and why I was calling them in the first place!! Deanna-- Thanks for your support.  I will look for the post you are referring to.  My med onc is the Director of Research at the hospital I'm being treated at, teaches at University of Toronto, and works out of two hospitals (albeit they are side by side), so initially I thought I was in great hands.......turns out her schedule might be a little too busy to be there for her patients' needs and concerns!  I will be questioning her initial lack of concern and I'm hoping her seeing my pictures might make her react quicker with the next poor women who goes through this.  Anyway she seems to be listening now and will acutally see me this Tues.  She has already decided that I will no longer be getting Taxotere, so maybe the chemo part of my tx might be finished .  I can live with that decision! Hugs and many thanks to all of you!!! Sandy
Posts.Title: Taxotere - BEWARE!! Beach Beach

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2009 07:19AM Beach wrote: hschwarzer--My heart goes out to you and your Mother!!  I can't imagine dealing with all of this and losing eyesight on top of this too.  It sounds like you are a great advocate and support system for her.....she is lucky to have you on her side!!  Sending positive thoughts to both of you! JourneyNC--So sorry about your reaction......what a frightening experience that must have been!!Sounds like you're in control of the situation now and you are right.......we must be our own advocates!!  All the best to you moving forward! Sandy
Posts.Title: Taxotere - BEWARE!! Beach Beach

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2009 10:00AM Beach wrote: Paulsgirl, It's hard to say because you are being hit with so much right now and your body is a little messed up.  Only time will tell once chemo has finished and time has passed.  Here's what happened to me: I'm 45 and was getting fairly regular periods prior to chemo.  My chemo regimen was 3 x FEC, 3 x Taxotere plus Herceptin.  Initially my period coincided with my chemo tx for all 3 FEC's..... meaning it was now happening every 3 weeks.  On the third FEC, it lasted a little longer, stopped but then started back up a week later and continued for about a month !!  Through this, my first Taxotere started and about a week after, the bleeding stopped.......this was the second week of June and I haven't had a period since.  During chemo tx I did experience night sweats but the hot flashes really didn't start until after the month of bleeding stopped.  Now I'm 7 wks out of chemo and no period yet......but the hot flashes and night sweats are definitely happening!!  Both my onc and my GP are taking the wait and see approach for the next year.  I'm definitely experiencing menopausal se's but apparently my period could still appear once the chemo se's leave my body for good............all the best to you!!
Posts.Title: Hot Flashes and Chemotherapy Sandals rdrake0

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 08:35AM Beach wrote: Hi all, I would like to join this thread eventhough I started rads yesterday.  I will be getting 16 sessions plus 5 boosts.  The simulation only took about 30 min and I left with 4 tattoos...........very tiny blue/black dots that I call "the world from space".  The first session yesterday went quicker than expected....I thought they were still taking pictures when they came into the room to tell me the radiation was done!  I was told not to put anything on my skin before tx but could use Lubriderm (unscented) or a Glaxal-based cream after each tx.  Lubriderm was suggested because it is a water-based cream.  Suggested that aloe vera is okay unless dryness/redness occurs, and if so, stop using it because it will dry the area out more. fmakj--I noticed you are from Ontario and you mentioned you are on a study.  Where are you being treated?  I'm being treated at Princess Margaret and I, too, am on a study that involved taking my blood. All the best to everybody going through or about to start rads...... Sandy
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 04:56PM Beach wrote: Piffken, This happened to me around my 3rd chemo tx.  I had finished my period and about 5 days later I started bleeding again.  It wasn't heavy but it was concerning as this continued daily for over a month.  Any doc or nurse I spoke with kept telling me not to be concerned but that's easier said than done at the time!  About 2 wks after my 4th chemo tx the bleeding stopped and I have not had a period or vaginal bleeding since.......that was the middle of June 09.  I'm 45 and my guess is that I was already heading into a peri-menopausal state when I was first dx and started treatment.  All the best to you!! Sandy
Posts.Title: Vaginal bleeding after first round of chemo anyone? Piffken buttonsmachine

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2009 10:27AM Beach wrote: Pam, I developed a cough right after my first Taxotere and Herceptin treatment and it has not let up.  Not sure which is causing it though, as I read in another thread that this can be caused by Herceptin. All the best to you, Sandy
Posts.Title: Does anyone know anything about Taxol and coughing? aris Bethie1

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 12:36PM Beach wrote: Sherry--Just back from my 2nd radiation and everything is good so far.  I'm starting with the Lubriderm and if any issues arise I'll figure it out from there.  I have been following the Ontario Get Together thread but I'm not available that day.......thanks though   Good luck next week....it's a walk in the park compared to chemo!! Chris--I remember that feeling after surgery.....couldn't drive for 2 wks because of the limited arm movement and felt like I had a serated knife in my armpit!  All I can say is that the exercises do help and it does get better but takes some time......probably good that you're not starting until 8/10.  Wishing you all the best!! Sandy
